Hi Chad, this idea of freezing certain preevolved portions of a 
network and letting it build on those is an interestng and viable 
research direction.  It is certainly one possible approach.  The 
representation isssue you bring up though is a problem for all of 
connectionism and machine learning in general: how should states be 
represented?  There is no single answer or method for deciding on 
representation and many times it comes down to an art form, and 
getting practice at seeing how different representations work with 
NN's.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> so let me try to summarize what you said.
> If I find a network that achieves some minimum fitness, adding new 
nodes
> and continuing the search would be the best way to minimize the 
search
> time.
> I do not, as you said, already have a monochrome network. I want 
to find
> a color network in a comparable amount of time to a monochrome 
network. 
> Are there ways of using previously discovered topologies to speed 
up
> searches? Something that comes to mind from colins advice is to 
have
> stratified features, and when one stratus of inputs reaches an
> acceptable fitness, freeze evolution on those elements, and force 
the
> new stratus of features to evolve around the previous features. 
This
> would keep the dimensionality the same, and assuming that each 
stratus
> was of comparable size, the search time would only increase 
linearly to
> the number of additional inputs.
> 
> Am I way out of my league, or is this in the right direction?
> 
> Chad
> 
> <-----Original Message-----> 
> From: Colin Green
> Sent: 5/5/2004 3:19:50 AM
> To: neat@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [neat] differentiation
> 
> Chad Bohannan wrote:
> 
> > how do you differentiate between similar types of information 
with
> NEAT?
> > I understand that the input should represent intensity, but what 
if I 
> > want to add more information? For instance: color.
> > The only approach I see is to just tack on inputs that begin the 
same 
> > as any other input. For a three color system, the eye just got 
three 
> > times many more dimensions complicated. Is there any way to 
scale from
> > a monochromatic solution to a color solution, without forcing a 
new 
> > search?
> 
> 
> Hi Chad, I would keep the monochromatic input and attach 3 new 
color 
> signals. That way previously evolved genomes can be used (with the 
new 
> inputs added) in the start population and mainatian their existing 
> functionality. You also might want to look at different color 
> representation systems, Red/Green/Blue is the system used in 
biological 
> eyes (or most of them AFAIK) but there are other schemes such as 
> Hue/Saturation//Brightness. So for instance in *that* scheme the 
> monochromatic input is effectively a brightness input so you only 
need 
> two more inputs.
> 
> Colin.
>
